title.value: LESS OR MORE FROM TEACHER: EXPLOITING TRILATERAL GEOMETRY FOR KNOWLEDGE DISTILLATION
title.justification: Title of the research paper provided in the user input.
title.quote: LESS OR MORE FROM TEACHER: EXPLOITING TRILATERAL GEOMETRY FOR KNOWLEDGE DISTILLATION

extractions.description: This paper introduces a novel method for knowledge distillation called TGeo-KD, which learns a sample-wise knowledge fusion ratio by leveraging trilateral geometric relations among student predictions, teacher predictions, and ground truths. The method is shown to be effective across various architectures and model sizes, with extensive experiments demonstrating consistent improvements over other loss re-weighting methods in tasks such as image classification, attack detection, and click-through rate prediction.

type.justification: The paper presents extensive experimental results and evaluations to demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method.
type.quote: Extensive experiments demonstrate consistent improvements over other loss re-weighting methods on image classification, attack detection, and click-through rate prediction.

name.justification: The main focus of the paper is on improving the process of knowledge distillation.
name.quote: Knowledge distillation aims to train a compact student network using soft supervision from a larger teacher network and hard supervision from ground truths.

name.justification: The paper demonstrates improvements in image classification, which is a primary task in computer vision.
name.quote: Extensive experiments demonstrate consistent improvements over other loss re-weighting methods on image classification, attack detection, and click-through rate prediction.

name.justification: The paper also addresses attack detection, which is relevant to cyber-physical systems.
name.quote: HIL (Pan et al., 2015) for attack detection in cyber-physical systems

name.justification: The paper includes experiments on click-through rate prediction, which is fundamental in recommender systems.
name.quote: Criteo (Jean-Baptiste Tien, 2014) for click-through rate (CTR) prediction in recommender systems.

name.justification: ResNet-34 is mentioned as one of the teacher networks used in the experiments.
name.quote: Figure 1: Motivation experiment on CIFAR-100 with a ResNet-34 teacher and a ResNet-18 student.

is_contributed.justification: The model itself is not a new contribution of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: ResNet-34 is used as a teacher model in the experiments.

is_executed.justification: The model is executed as part of the experiments in the study.
is_executed.quote: The student is trained with varying knowledge fusion ratio values (α).

is_compared.justification: The performance of the models is compared in various experiments.
is_compared.quote: We propose to learn the fusion ratio by a neural network (NN) and formulate KD as a bilevel objective that leverages the trilateral geometric information. As a result, the student is influenced by a tailored blend of knowledge from both the teacher and the ground truth.
